Posts.Content: Hi Pennymoon, so sorry after all that time you're going through it again, something I'm sure we all dread.. poor you I don't know what stage of treatment you're at so this may not be helpful but thought I'd mention it.  I read on the Anastrozole instructions that we must inform our dentist that we're taking it. I saw my dentist last week and mentioned it. He looked up the reason and said the medication can cause dry mouth which in turn can cause build up of tartar, plaque.  Apart from telling me to drink water, even if it's sipping often, he said if it gets bad he can recommend a spray that my gp can prescribe.  Apparently Anastrozole can also be a cause of mouth soreness and ulcers.  Hope that may be of some help at some time.. Good luck with all treatment. Hugs, Annie ❤ xxxx
Posts.Title: Oh my mouth...

Posts.Content: Just like you Mavi I was always the one who helped others. Cared for elderly aunts for years, am my disabled son’s carer.Usually the one driving, picking up friends etc. .Never in my life had I “given in” but I didn’t ask for help, it was offered. I could have driven myself but my husband and my daughter really wanted to be there for me, so I let them be! And I was so greatful for their company, plus I honestly believe it did them some good to be involved as they were so worried (more than I was to be honest!) and better to be with me than sitting at home worrying and wondering.. Friends offered lifts too and if needed I’d have asked.. Yes, take your O/H tomorrow. Take books, iPad, magazines if you’re in for a long day?  The worst part is the waiting. Once you’re started you get into a routine and before you know it, it’ll be over! Hope all goes well.  If you celebrate it, I hope you manage to enjoy Christmas. Xxx
Posts.Title: New to site and recently diagnosed

Posts.Content: Hi Mavi. Really sorry you’ve had such rubbish news and just before Christmas too.. But. The main thing is that you’re on it, you’re going to be treated, you’ve caught it early. I think it’s great you can work from home! That will be a godsend I’m sure.  It’s ok to cry, it’s better to release your feelings than hold them in.  I don’t know if you have Facebook and messenger, but what I did was to start messenger groups. I put my family into one, and different friends into a couple of others. That way I could let them all know as much (or as little) as I wanted to. And it saved me from repeating myself over and over. I’d copy and paste the same messages adding or deleting bits here and there. They could then respond as they wished and their messages were very comforting.  Once your treatment starts you may feel a bit better, you’re told what to do, you’re looked after. You can stop wondering what’s going to happen once it’s happening!  My advice.. If people offer to accompany you, give you lifts, take them up on it. Allow them to help. It’s nice to have company at hospitals, and it’s good to talk! .  Let us know how you’re getting on. Good luck. Love and hugs. Annie xxx ❤️❤️❤️
Posts.Title: New to site and recently diagnosed

I'd take it easy, do your exercises, and wait to see what's next before making definite work plans? Good luck! ❤️❤️❤️ Xx

Posts.Title: Abnormal lack of feelings?

Posts.Content: Hi Rosie,  I was exactly the same. Having had aunts, sisters and a niece with breast cancer it didn't come as a shock to me when told I'd got it too. I think some others around me were far more upset and concerned for me than I was! And I'm quite sure everyone was waiting for me to break down. But like you, I just thought, right, this is how it is, you're  getting all necessary treatment, get on with it. Having said that,  I fully understand why others can't think like that because we're all different with very different emotions. The only one time I shed tears (apologies to anyone who's  already read this as I've said it before) was my daughter telling me about my grandson's reaction. He was 13 last year when I was diagnosed. The Christmas before I'd bought him one of those leather bracelets with a little tag that says something about him being a lovely grandson. Knowing what he's like, I'd said I didn't mind if he never actually wore it but would like him to keep it even if it went in a drawer! My daughter said after she'd told my grandchildren about me he went off and shut himself away in his  bedroom. Then when he appeared again later he was wearing the bracelet. He's a quiet lad, doesn't show his feelings very much so I can't tell you how much that touched me.. Other than that, no, I've been fine and it's coming up to a year ago  since I finished radiotherapy. No tears, no real worries. It was here and now it's gone ❤️ Love to one and all xxx
Posts.Title: Abnormal lack of feelings?

Posts.Title: Teeth after treatments

Posts.Content: Hi Nette, I noticed on the leaflet with my Anastrozole it said to inform your dentist you're taking it which I did. He looked it up and explained to me that the medication can cause very dry mouth which in turn can cause build up of tartare more easily causing decay. He suggested sipping water regularly to prevent my mouth drying which I try to do.  I've had a bit of a problem on and off though recently and he's told me I could have a tooth that's slowly dying off (don't know which one as the pain seemed to be all across one side of my mouth) but an X-ray won't show the problem so I have to go in straight away when the pain returns.  I'm 66 so suppose it's expected I might get the odd problem but I was surprised as my dental health score is 2 which is apparently pretty good.  The problems seem to never end!!  Good luck with your treatment, I used to be terrified too but it's all so much improved from years ago and I'm sure you'll be fine.  Love and hugs, Annie xx ❤️

Posts.Title: Stitches

Posts.Content: Hi Vicky, I'm so sorry you're feeling so worried and upset but I really do understand. The good thing is you've acted straight away, and let's hope it's an annoying cyst!  This past three weeks I've been attending a "Moving forward after breast cancer" course. There are quite a lot of us attending, all ages, all having had  different types of ops and cancers. Some have had chemotherapy , some radiotherapy.  The main thing is, we are all here! We are all alive and kicking and talking about our holidays!  Having breast cancer these days is far more treatable than ever, we're actually very lucky to have such wonderful staff to care for us and fantastic treatment available. Saying that, an aunt of mine had breast cancer when she was forty. She passed away just two years ago from natural causes aged 'one hundred and one'!!!! And bear in mind the treatment back then wasn't anywhere near as good as it is now. So please, please don't think that even IF you have breast cancer it's a death sentence!!   But we're jumping way ahead. I really hope you come back here and tell us it was a false alarm. If not, come and talk to us. There are some lovely ladies on here, always ready to chat and listen.  Easy for anyone to tell you not to worry because you still will, that's absolutely natural. Try to store your scary thoughts away in a box. Leave the box closed, throw it out if you can. Do some nice things with your daughters if you're able to, anything to take your mind off it and please stop googling lol! We've all done it and trust me, it doesn't help!!  Big hugs, hope all turns out well. Annie Xxx ❤️❤️❤️

Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Hi Evie, I have to say I was really shocked to see Brave the Shave on tv again!! In spite of me not having lost my hair I know that if I had, i'd find this very upsetting, in fact it upsets me anyway! . I recently attended "Moving Forward after Breast Cancer" and some of the ladies had hair loss, most had it growing back but it broke my heart to see so many beautiful women feeling so upset with their hair loss. Strangely enough over the four weeks course we didn't talk about fund raising of any kind, I wish now I'd brought up the subject of this shaving to fund raise to see how everyone felt. I know if I'd gone through hair loss the thought of any of my family or friends shaving their heads horrifies me! I'm really surprised and shocked Macmillan haven't taken any notice of the amount of people who're against it. I wonder why they've allowed it? X❤️❤️❤️X
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: I absolute agree. I've had radiotherapy not chemo but I've always thought if ever I did have chemo and lost my hair, the very last thing I'd want would be anyone losing theirs to "make me feel better" because it absolutely wouldn't. In fact I'd be so distressed if my daughter or grandchildren were to shave off their beautiful hair!  The other thing I thoroughly dislike are the posts I see on face book of women who've had breast cancer showing their breasts, their scars. No one needs to see that, no matter what age, no matter how severe or not your scars are.. We don't see people showing any other results from other operations, I just don't see the need.. It most certainly doesn't make me feel better about my now disfigured breast! the last thing I could ever do is show anyone my scars.. It's not brave, it's not helpful. In fact I think it could make some women feel even more terrified that they could end up looking like that.  So I agree, stop the shaving of heads and stop the naked breasts. Please.

Posts.Title: Anastrozole and hair dye.

Posts.Content: I agree. I think it's very difficult (especially in this day and age of political correctness) for people to know what to say without causing offence. I've had some weird things said to me and I only had radiotherapy after my lumpectomy so luckily didn't lose my hair. But I've felt quite irritated at times, one friend comparing my breast cancer with her having the bags under her eyes done.. Almost everyone starts telling you about "so and so" who had "this or that operation"  who survived, who died etc etc... But I know everyone has tried their best to be kind. So I've just smiled and let it all pass over me.. Nothing anyone says can really and truly help us feel better.. In some ways I feel like I've had to put others at ease, make them feel better! But after all I've been through (and I know many of you lovely ladies have been through far worse)  I'm just glad my cancer was found early, glad I've been cared for so well by our NHS, glad I'm still here and people and things are not going to be allowed to bother me like they used to!  Love 'n hugs xxx ❤️

Posts.Content: Hi Flopsyuk. I'm coming up to a year in June since I finished radiotherapy. My nipple is still discoloured but lighter than it was a year ago. I have felt fobbed off too but then I think am I just being impatient? My mammogram has come back clear (thank goodness) I was told last week that healing takes longer in some than others as I'm still feeling discomfort, can't lie on that breast in bed for long and thought by now it'd be back to "normal" though of course it'll never look the same again. I'm just going to tell myself I'm luckier than a lot of women, I still have my boobs! Or at least, one and three quarter boobs!  We have to trust the experts but I was told in no uncertain terms that if anything doesn't feel right, if I'm at all worried, to not wait for my next mammogram but get in touch and go in to see them. One suggestion I'd give  is to write everything down that you want to ask. It's so easy to forget what you want to say when in with the doctor.. good luck, hope all goes well. Annie xxx ❤️

Posts.Title: Hereditary breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Karen, thank you for your reply, it is very interesting, especially about post menopausal women and new research.. We also have suspicions the cancer is on our paternal side., my great aunt and my aunt were my on my Dads side, plus he had brothers who had cancer.  I really don't think anything should be dismissed because anything's possible isn't it.  I do agree with you about screening. Both myself and my sister who've had lumpectomies had our cancer discovered during routine screening, whereas my sister who died (following her mastectomy as the cancer was very aggressive and spread rapidly) had never attended her mammogram appointments and by the time hers was discovered it really was too late. In fact she died 12 years ago today. And then in the following years it's been another sister and then now myself. Interestingly, our eldest sister is 85 (20 years older than me) and it was her daughter who died aged 49 but this sister has, thankfully, remained cancer free.  I hope all goes well for you also in the future Karen. Love Ann xx
